quote: I put the fear of death in the cyclists [during orientation remarks] the night before. It's worked every year. I tell them to take it down two notches from what they would ride at home on the descents. If you fall, it's really hard to rescue you. And if you make a wrong turn, you go to Mexico.
You have 10 hours to ride your bike to the border of Mexico and back.
Riders spend most of the day moving through the wide expanse of the San Rafael Valley, a high grass valley buffeted by the Patagonia Mountains, the Canelo Hills, and the Huachuca Mountains.
The first climb out of Patagonia and up Harshaw Creek Road gets me every time — does that look like what you imagine when you think of southern Arizona?
Every course distance brushes the border between Arizona and Mexico — those mountains lie beyond a wall that is visible from the course.
Saturday morning at 7:00 A.M., the Spirit World 100 begins with a three-mile neutral roll-out on pavement, led by the local border patrol.
A LIGHTLY MARKED COURSE - You are required to upload your course on a GPS to ensure that you do not miss a turn! Signage will be limited.

The Boomshakalaka Bar, the race's final aid station, sits near the base of the rocky outcropping. Legend has it that Heidi Ault exclaimed 'Boomshakalaka!' upon seeing the views for the first time on a bike ride there five years ago. On tap at the Boomshakalaka Bar: ice cold Coca-Cola.

While there is certainly a race at the Spirit World 100, it doesn't necessarily resemble other events where group dynamics dominate. Could it be the small field? The late date? The distance from most places? Somehow, racing in the spirit world is different.
Only a handful of punctures and one broken pedal constituted the event's round-up of mechanicals.

This was a really cool year. It was the first year that we really felt like we had the time and the ability to reach out to our local downtown business sector... Quail Covey was super-supportive this year. Red Mountain Foods jumped on board, Queen of Cups, Mary Tolena's Terrasol.
The Aults have crafted the Spirit World 100 to be unlike any other gravel race. It bursts with sights, sounds, and smells specific to the region, as well as to the couple's own taste.
I think what we set out to do originally with this event was to set up an atmosphere where any type of rider would feel comfortable attending. And that's continued.
